properties.Name: MecClassificationType
properties.Description:
Congress established the Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act (1988), known as TAMRA, which revised the tax law definition of a 'life insurance contract' to discourage the sale and purchase of life insurance for investment purposes or as a tax shelter.

This created a new class of insurance known as Modified Endowment Contracts, MECs.

If an insurance product is deemed to be a MEC it will be taxed and not receive favorable tax treatment.

If a policy is assigned a MEC classification and the owner receives an amount from it in the form of a loan or withdrawal, that amount will be taxed first as ordinary income and then second as return of premium if there is any gain in the contract over the amount of premiums paid.

There is also a 10% penalty tax imposed on these amounts if they are received before the policyowners age 59.5.

To avoid being classified as a MEC, the insurance policy must meet the '7-pay test', which states that if the total amount a policyholder pays into a life insurance contract during the first years exceeds the sum of the net level premiums that would have been payable to provide paid-up future benefits in seven years, the policy is in fact a 'MEC' and will remain so throughout its duration.

Columns.Name: MecClassificationTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the insurance policy MEC type.

Columns.Name: MecClassificationTypeName
Columns.Description: The name of the insurance policy MEC type.

Columns.Name: MecClassificationTypeDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the insurance policy MEC type.

Properties.Description:
Congress established the Technical and Miscellaneous Revenue Act (1988), known as TAMRA, which revised the tax law definition of a 'life insurance contract' to discourage the sale and purchase of life insurance for investment purposes or as a tax shelter.

This created a new class of insurance known as Modified Endowment Contracts, MECs.

If an insurance product is deemed to be a MEC it will be taxed and not receive favorable tax treatment.

If a policy is assigned a MEC classification and the owner receives an amount from it in the form of a loan or withdrawal, that amount will be taxed first as ordinary income and then second as return of premium if there is any gain in the contract over the amount of premiums paid.

There is also a 10% penalty tax imposed on these amounts if they are received before the policyowners age 59.5.

To avoid being classified as a MEC, the insurance policy must meet the '7-pay test', which states that if the total amount a policyholder pays into a life insurance contract during the first years exceeds the sum of the net level premiums that would have been payable to provide paid-up future benefits in seven years, the policy is in fact a 'MEC' and will remain so throughout its duration.
